profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-04-04 12:06:37 -0400.

did.physloc: Boxes 1-14 (RRMV5/S2-C-Top); Boxes 15-20 (RRMV5/S2-D-Top); Boxes 21-28 (RRMV5/S2-E-Top); Boxes 29, 32-34, 36, 38, 51-57 (RRMV5/S2-F-Top); Boxes 30-31, 35, 37, 39-50 (RRMV/Cold Storage)
did.abstract: Robert Rauschenberg, an American artist, worked in a wide range of subjects, styles, materials, and techniques and has been called a forerunner of essentially every postwar movement since Abstract Expressionism. He remained, however, independent of any particular affiliation. Active from the late-1940s to 2008, his practice embodied lifelong commitment to collaboration and he worked performers, printmakers, engineers, writers, artists, and artisans from around the world.

Materials in the Audiovisual Collection document Rauschenberg and his artistic pursuits, including footage and news coverage of artworks, exhibitions and performances. Recordings relating to the artist's personal life and interests, including his social and political involvement, are also present.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into eight series: 1. Artists, Organizations and People; 2. Artwork; 3. Exhibitions and Projects; 4. Found Footage; 5. Off-Air Broadcast Recordings; 6. Performance; 7. Personal and Biographical; Series 8. Unidentified; and Series 9. Separated Housings.

accessrestrict.head: Restriction
accessrestrict.p: As of March 2016, only digital surrogates are available for access. All other items are restricted. Please contact the Archives for more information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Audiovisual Collection. RRFA 02. Robert Rauschenberg Foundation Archives, New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Materials in the Audiovisual Collection document Rauschenberg's artistic pursuits and personal activities as well as his associations with other artists, arts professionals, and arts organizations. The collection includes footage of Rauschenberg creating artworks, installations and openings of his exhibitions, and performances in which he participated or contributed design elements. Many of Rauschenberg's projects, exhibitions, and performances are also documented in contemporaneous news coverage, interviews with curators, and full-length documentary works. Biographical materials in the collection feature recordings such as artist statements and biographical pieces created by the artist, lectures and symposia covering a range of social and arts-related topics in which he participated, and testimonies given before the U.S. Congress. Personal and collected recordings such as home movies, industrial and education films, and off-air recordings of television broadcasts are also present.

The collection is comprised of seven hundred sixteen analog video recordings on a variety of formats, over eighty-nine films, seventy-one sound recordings and three hundred thirty-eight digital objects. Items that have Foundation assigned registration numbers are indicated in the finding aid.
As of March 2016, only digital objects (digital videos and digital surrogates of analog videos) are available for viewing and access. Digital objects are also indicated in the finding aid.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.p: Robert Rauschenberg: A Retrospective, edited by Susan Davidson and Walter Hopps, pp. 206–23. Exh. cat. New York: Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1997.

physdesc.physfacet: 32 analog video recordings; 12 digital videos and surrogates

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series 2. Artwork documents Rauschenberg's artworks and his art practices. Highlights include the artist's film work "Canoe" and the sound track to "The ¼ Mile or 2 Furlong." Documentary recordings include footage of art making, installations and restoration, maintenance instructions, and news coverage relating to particular works and series. The series is comprised of thirty-two analog video recordings, three 16 mm films, one sound recording, and twelve digital videos and surrogates.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically by artwork title. Cross-references are provided for agents and subjects which appear elsewhere in the archives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series 6. Performance contains materials relating to performances that Rauschenberg choreographed, performed in or created set pieces and media works for as well as documentation regarding choreographers with whom he collaborated. The recordings include footage and sound recordings of performances and rehearsals, excerpt compilations and documentaries, and original film and sound works created for performance pieces. Highlights include 16 mm films of Rauschenberg's "Linoleum" as well as masters and source materials for "Elastic Carrier" made for Trisha Brown's "Set and Reset." The series is comprised of ninety analog video recordings, twenty-nine 16 mm films, twelve sound recordings, and fifty-nine digital surrogates.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged alphabetically by personal name of the choreographer or by the name of the event. Cross-references are provided for agents and subjects which appear elsewhere in the archives.

odd.head: General Note
odd.p: The recordings include various excerpts of Robert Rauschenberg's "Pelican" and "Map Room II," Alex Hay's "Leadville," and Deborah Hay's "They Will" (originally "Would They Wouldn't They,") and "Victory 14."

odd.head: General Note
odd.p: One box is also labeled "Mystery (Aion) (Gnonthic)".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Recordings in Series 7. Personal and Biographical relate to Rauschenberg's personal life and narrative. These materials include personal recordings made by the artist of his travels and celebrations with friends, biographical works and news coverage describing Rauschenberg's career and influence, and award ceremonies given in his honor. Other recordings include artist statements and biographies made by the artist, interviews and lectures he gave, and testimonies delivered before the U.S. Congress. Highlights include Super 8 films of Rauschenberg's home in Captiva and source materials from the unfinished Jacques Clement film "Mostly About Rauschenberg" that feature Rauschenberg talking about his work. The series is comprised of one hundred twenty-nine analog video recordings, thirty-four 16 mm films, thirty-four sound recordings, two Super 8 films, and one hundred eighteen digital videos and surrogates.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series has been arranged alphabetically into the following sub-series: Awards, Biography, Films, Home movies and sound recordings, Instructional videos, Interviews, Lectures and Symposia, Legal, Memorial, Radio, Social and political, and Television and serials. Cross-references are provided for agents and subjects which appear elsewhere in the archives.
